quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Waves
quiz.subtitle: Unit 8, Quiz 9: Advanced Wave Interference & Standing Waves
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: A string of length L is fixed at both ends. If it is vibrating in its third harmonic, how many antinodes are present in the standing wave pattern?
questions.explanation: In a standing wave on a string fixed at both ends, the number of antinodes (vibrating loops) corresponds exactly to the harmonic number (n).

questions.question: Two identical wave pulses with positive amplitudes of 3 cm and 5 cm meet at a single point. What is the resulting displacement at the moment of maximum overlap?
questions.explanation: According to the Principle of Superposition, when two pulses with the same sign overlap, their amplitudes add together: 3 cm + 5 cm = 8 cm.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions must be met to produce a stable standing wave pattern on a string?
options: Two waves of the same frequency and amplitude must travel in opposite directions.
Two waves of different frequencies must travel in the same direction.
A single wave must travel through a vacuum without any boundaries.
The medium must be changing density constantly.
questions.explanation: Standing waves are formed by the interference of an incident wave and its reflected wave, which have identical frequency and amplitude but opposite directions.

questions.question: For a string of length L fixed at both ends, what is the wavelength of the second harmonic (n=2)?
questions.explanation: The second harmonic contains two loops, which equals one full wavelength. Therefore, the length of the string L equals the wavelength λ.

questions.question: If two sound sources are out of phase by 180°, and a listener is exactly the same distance from both, what will the listener hear?
options: A sound twice as loud as a single source
A sound with double the frequency
questions.explanation: Because the sources are 180° out of phase and the path difference is zero, a crest from one source always meets a trough from the other, resulting in total destructive interference.

questions.question: A standing wave on a string has 4 nodes in total, including the two fixed ends. Which harmonic is the string vibrating in?
questions.explanation: The number of nodes is always n + 1, where n is the harmonic number. If there are 4 nodes, it is the 3rd harmonic (n=3).

questions.question: When two waves undergo destructive interference, what happens to the energy of the waves at the point of cancellation?
options: It is redistributed to other areas, such as antinodes.
It is permanently lost from the system.
It is stored as potential energy at the node.
questions.explanation: Energy cannot be destroyed. In interference patterns, the energy is redistributed from the nodes to the antinodes where constructive interference occurs.

questions.question: If the frequency of a standing wave on a fixed string is doubled, what happens to the number of antinodes?
options: The number of antinodes stays the same.
The number of antinodes is halved.
The number of antinodes increases by one.
questions.explanation: Since frequency is proportional to the harmonic number (f_n = n * f_1), doubling the frequency doubles n, which represents the number of antinodes.

questions.question: Two pulses travel toward each other. Pulse A has an amplitude of +4 m and Pulse B has an amplitude of -6 m. What is the displacement at the instant they fully overlap?
questions.explanation: Adding the displacements vectorially: +4 m + (-6 m) = -2 m.

questions.question: In the third harmonic of a standing wave on a string, how much of a wavelength is contained within the length of the string?
questions.explanation: The third harmonic consists of 3 half-wavelength loops. 3 * (λ/2) = 1.5λ.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! Your understanding of harmonics and superposition is very strong.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Review the node/antinode count for different harmonics.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Remember that each loop is only half a wavelength.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on the basics of the Superposition Principle and standing wave diagrams.
